description.text:
I was in my studio at the weekend to laser these cool gamecontroller. If you want to reproduce it you just need a lasercutter and RDWOrks V8. The RDWorks-Project files is an attachment. In the RDWorks Project file all nessesary properties have been defined. Just scale the design and download it to your cutter. Hint: You arent limited to a lasercutter with the Adobe Illustrator file. Go to a Plotter or a CNC if you have the possibility.

Just Follow me here for more awesome projects in the future :-)

If you are interested than take a look (German):
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IGypDoUtaLk
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/IGypDoUtaLk" ></iframe>

Welcome to Lightpainting!

Lightpainting is fun with your camera on bulb mode in the night
The camera stands on a tripod, fixing to an object in the dark.
in the time the camera is open, you can use any light to move in the picture. Your body will not be visible because its dark and you are moving. So you can paint with light.

With this tool you can create a colorfull lightsource for lightning rooms or objects.

There are three buttons for setting a RGB-basecolor. A Startbutton switches the light on or off.
With the brightness button you can set the brightness of your lightning or effects or (long pressed) you can switch, that the startbutton must be hold while lightning or acts like a On/Off button.
All settings are presented in a simple menü throught the leds.

With the anmiation button you can choose several anjmations: Simple-Color, rainbow cycling (Solid or dynamic), fadeout your choosen color or stroboscop flashes.

The pistol is very bright and the angle of lighting ist wide. Therefore i have added a snooze for this pistol, which ist optional. It allows better control for setting color points in your scene.

On ebay you can purchase neopixel-like rings, 4 sizes in one circuit board (normaly, you broke them in several rings but here let them together and solder only the pins together, start with the inner ring, second ring, fourth ring und third ring)

The pistol offers a battery case for 4 AA-batteries.
It can be hold in one hand, which can switch the buttons, so you have the other hand for your camera

Heart of the pistol is an naked arduino nano, i have soldered the switches an RGB leds direct on the board.
The sourcecode for the arduino comes with this thing!

Have fun on lightpainting!

description.text:
While working on a couple of xyz da vinci jr 1.0 units I noticed they kept having issue's with feeding which was due to the pneumatic fitting loosing strength and allowing the bowden tubing to come loose causing complete loss of tension for pushing the filament through the hotend. To resolve the issue I took the feeder motor out of the unit and replaced the feeder portions attached to the motor with an aluminum extruder block off amazon (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B014SB12Q2/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1)

One other thing to note, I also replaced the hotend of the unit using a hotend off amazon as well (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01GD8LCFO/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o04_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1) so I am not sure if the pneumatic fitting from the stock bowden tube works with the block linked above.

I then needed a way to mount the moto back to the framing and after searching around thingiverse and not finding something usefull I came up with this simple design.

Some day I will get around to creating an actual hot end mount that is compatible with the xyz da vinci jr carriage. Until then I just used one I found on here.

author: Nadica

description.text:
Less of a "Thing" and more of instructions for setting up VNC-based 3d-printer station.
I also had at least 5 people ask me how to do this. So, here we are - now I can point here.
I had an IdeaCenter attached to the back of one of my monitors that I was no longer using as a NAS and was tired of configuring every stinking computer I used to 3d print, swap the USB cable, blah... blah...
So, I used the IdeaCenter as a printer station and accessing it via VNC.

1) Set up a low end computer with sufficient capability to serve VNC and your 3D printer application. Test that it works as a printer and is networked with VNC.
In my case I used:
  • IdeaCenter Q100
  • Ubuntu 10.10 X86
  • Printrun (SFACT - but it is seldom used)
    • 2) On the printer server system "share" a space on the drive with sufficient access for you to write and read via your workstation. Install your slicer and its configuration files for your workstation on this share. 3) Use a VNC configuration file to retain the settings to connect to it (see the VNC file attached) 4) Slice the part on your workstation and put its gcode files onto the shared drive created in step #2 above. 5) Connect to printer server via VNC and load the GCODE file. 6) Enjoy being able to:
  • manage the printer settings on only one computer
  • take your workstation off line and still print
  • share the printer with others on the network
    • HaHa - oops I forgot to add that I printed a few parts via VNC from my Xoom tablet.

author: Kldz

title: 5x5 Hexagonal Prism Twisty Puzzle (Printed Extensions Only, No Cutting Required)

description.text:
Files are back, and I completed mine!

IMPORTANT: Print the inner three layers as-is. You need to scale the top and bottom layers in ONLY THE Z AXIS. How to find out how much:

(X/Y) = (1/12) whree Y = the thickness of top/bottom layers on your puzzle. Solve for X to get your scale. In other words, ((Y * 1) / 12) or (Y / 12).

--If using Shengshou, Y = 13. Scale by 1.08333. This is a tested and perfect fit!--

Theres a bit of a hexagonal prism trend going on in the twisty puzzling community. I have not seen a 5x5 version yet. So here's mine.

A 5x5 puzzle with pieces 12.05mmx12.05mm will work. As it happens, the
New Shengshou 5x5 is what I designed this for. Note that it is listed and sold as a 64mm cube, but the pieces are not 64mm/5 pieces. Just get the shengshou 5x5, or measure your 5x5's pieces.

If you print all the extensions, you will not need to cut/sand/fill any parts of your 5x5. The finished puzzle will have an approximate width of about 88.5mm and a height of 64mm, with an edge length of 50.8mm.

Make sure your printer is calibrated before printing. You can print each of the 90 total extensions seperately, or print one entire layer of 18 pieces. You must print 5 of each part (Extension(1-18)x5), or 5 of the (FullLayerx5) models.

If you make one, PLEASE post a make! I, and others looking to make one themselves would love to see it.

I started by modeling 12.05mm cubes, in a 5x5x5 grid, with a very small gap in between. This resulted in a cube with an edge length of 62.6mm, which is what I measured with my calipers on my cube. I then created a hexagon whose edges matched two corners of the cube, which meant it is the smallest hexagon that can possibly fit the cube inside it, which means no cutting required.

I then created a larger cube as a sketch above the cube. I extended every face of the cube until it went past the hexagon i sketched earlier, and used it to cut around the cube and creat ethe shape. I can very easily create other amount of sides with this method, and I plan to later.

Then I deleted everything but the one layer (in hindsight, this is the only layer I had to model.) and fillet all of the edges that needed fillet.

title: HAM-STD HS1-712 Airfoil Micro Drone Propeller (14.50g thrust @ 3V)

description.text:
Note: This propeller under-performed below reasonable expectations. Maybe do a re-print / re-test (if anyone is interested?).
This micro drone propeller was designed using the HAM-STD HS1-712 airfoil. It was tested on the Drone Propeller Thrust Testing Jig (all of the results can be seen below).

Part printed at slow speed, by using a 0.2mm extruder nozzle at 0.04 layer height. The print was cleaned using a Precision Knife

After this, I then got to finish the propeller using a 400 grit sandpaper.

These are the measurements for the 4 picked voltage values (you can also check these out in the images):

  • 1.5V => 3.75 grams
  • 2V => 6.39 grams
  • 2.5V => 14.11 grams
  • 3V => 14.5 grams

The included files contain all the pictures taken during the test, with 6 text files that have all the airfoil coordinates used in the build, the printable STL files and the SLDPRT files. Should you like to play with this propeller, make sure you have a few 8520 coreless motors.

You can use the SLDPRT files, in case you desire to adapt the propeller model to suit your own needs.

P.S. Airfoil plotted with the matplotlib library for python.

print_settings.Notes:: This model is designed to be printed in TPU for flexibility.  That is what allows you to bend it easily to clip onto miniature bases without risking damage to the base.

description.text:
So, have you ever been playing a tabletop RPG (Pathfinder, for instance...) and the GM decides they're going to throw a multitude of something at you to fight. Usually you say "Orc 1, orc 2, orc 3, etc..." Then comes the fun of remembering which one on the map is which creature.

We ran into this in our bi-weekly game. So I made some simply counters we could clip the figures into to denote numeration. The originals were a crafting project with foam sheets and glue, then I redid them in TinkerCAD once I bought a printer. Due to needing a flexible part I printed them in TPU.

Full disclosure : This is my first ever project to design myself, I know the numbers aren't perfectly aligned for instance. I full expect that it's primative, but it worked well for me. Please let me know if there are newbie mistakes I made, or improvements that could be done.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

25%

Notes:

I printed these on a PowerSpec Ultra 3d Printer.

The material used was TPU
Extrusion temp was 220 degrees
Bed temp was 70 degrees
Cooling fan was set to "auto"

This model is designed to be printed in TPU for flexibility. That is what allows you to bend it easily to clip onto miniature bases without risking damage to the base.

After printing....

After printing I simply went over the numbers with a sharpie to make them more readable. When I master multi-material printing I will probably print them into the counters with black ABS or PLA.

The process....

I did the originals of these using sheet foam, an exacto knife, and glue years ago. Once I got a 3d printer I figured I would try to replicate them , but better.
Working on a new direction which I call Klee Symbols. They are a mix between the enigmatic symbols in some of Paul Klee's paintings, Henry Moore's sculptures, and Alexander Calder's stabiles.

Trophies to be awarded to the fastest pilots at a drone race.

These trophies feature a spinning propeller and race organization logo. Fork the OnShape document to customize for your organization.

Construction of the trophies requires a 608 bearing, 5in prop, and super glue.

These can be purchased on amazon:
Bearings: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B002BBGTK6/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o05_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
Prop: https://www.amazon.com/s/ref=nb_sb_noss?url=search-alias%3Daps&field-keywords=5in+5045+prop
Glue: https://www.amazon.com/Loctite-Purpose-Adhesive-1-75-Fluid-1661510/dp/B0098T94KQ/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1494778728&sr=8-1&keywords=loctite+go2+glue

Instructions:
1) Print all parts
2) Insert the axis through the 608 bearing
3) Attach a prop to the axis
4) Push the 608 bearing into the trophy
5) Glue the trinket to the top of the prop

Designed in OnShape. Feel free to fork the design and customize for your organization.

description.text: Playable Cajon has 2 prints; the body (long print) and the playing surface. The only thing I don't like is a strange buzzing sound from the snares; perhaps I made them too long or may be able to get the buzz out with adjustments.

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

High

Infill:

30

Notes:

Printing the body is a long 38 hour print at 30% infill. The playing surface is about a 4 hour print.

Tools and supplies

1) Small screw driver
2) 14 flat sheet metal screws #2 x 3/8
3) Thin and bendable metal wire about 1mm thick
4) Printed Body and playing surface
5) Pliers or something to help bend the thin metal wire
6) Wire cutters

Using pliers fold the thin metal wire to this shape and cut off any extra wire. There is no exact measurement for how long you want the wires, if you want you can even put in a second folded wire. On mine I made the wire go almost to the bottom of the cajon. More contact more snare sound. Place the folded wire in the slot on the body (I consider this the top). Make sure the wire sticks out above the cajon so it will contact the playing surface. Again -- more contact more snare sound. You can also see here you may be able to squeeze in a second wire. Place the playing surface over the cajon body and line up the pilot holes. The wires pushing up make this a little tricky until the first couple screws are in. Start to screw in the screws partially. Make sure all of the screws are in before you tighten any of them all the way. Make sure all of the screws are in before tightening. I like to tighten the screws the same as a drum head or car tire. Pick a screw then go straight across; try to make the tension as equal as you can. PLAY!

<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/N8zdi2edMV4" ></iframe>

Since one way coffee capsules are a waste of resources, several refillable models exist.  
This is a simple spoon to hold the capsule during refilling.  
The included OpenSCAD source can be modified via parameters to fit it to your capsule. Default of the included STL File is a diameter of 28mm. Since the capsules are conical, this should fit for the most models.

No special instructions.
I printed it with the ultimaker on 100 mm/s and a layer height of 0.1mm and 0.2mm. Thicker layers should also be fine but the grip holes may look ugly. You can also turn them off in the OpenSCAD file.

description.text:
this is a basic suppressor for .177 air rifles. if you're careful with tolerances it should fit a .22 AIR rifle, too. do not be a dummy and do not stick this on a proper .22lr gun. if you do however, make sure to record everything for youtube fame.
it's designed to clamp on to a 15.25mm thick barrel with a cutout for stock iron sights. this should fit a diana 25, norinco b1 and b2, and perfecta 32 just right, but watch out for your optic's axis. the internal channel is 6mm wide, so you shouldn't have to worry about baffle strikes.
it's supposed to be printed standing up, internal support structures aren't required because of the extreme baffle angles.
my first print fell over because of adhesive failure to the base plate (abs print, plate too cold, warpage visible in pictures), so i shortened it to compensate. it failed right before the end, so i printed out a sleeve that fits the first 80%. this monstrosity i took pictures of, but it still worked as intended.
the next version will be much flatter, longer, and printed on its sides.

title: Customizable comfy spinner caps. Cap for any bearing.

description.text:
Comfy caps for any bearing (just specify a model of bearing)
with easy removing support and easy printing (no need additinional support and brim in slicer)
No need sanding after printing.
Supported 31 models of bearings. (и еще 54 типа подшипников по ГОСТУ)
Ready stl for standart 608 and 627,629,696,698 bearings (for nozzle <=0.5 and layer<=0.12)
Parameters:
// minimal diameter of cap, for default 2/3 of outer bearing dimension
dMin = 19;
// thickness of cap
tCap = 1.6;
// model of bearing
model = 608;
// quantity
qty = 2;
// tolerance > 0 for snug fit
o = 0.03;
// true for slot
slot = true;
// depth of pit
pit = 1.2;
You can turn off auto-support in openscad (or in customizer) (set support=false).
Thick of support depends on parameters:
nozzle =0.5;
layer =0.13;
you can set nozzle of you printer and layer which you want.

If you prefer flat caps: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2301451

description.text:
The Venus of Arles is a 1.94-metre-high (6.4 ft) sculpture of Venus at the Musée du Louvre. It is in Hymettus marble and dates to the end of the 1st century BC.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venus_of_Arles

My scan is made from a 1:1 plaster cast of the head. It took me about 10 hours to digitalize and process the model.

The STL is 1:1, about 38 cms tall, so you have to adjust to the size you want.

You´ll need support for chin, hair and nose.

title: Boeing KC-135 Winglet Supercritical Whitcomb Airfoil Micro Drone Propeller (30.72g thrust @3V)

description.text:
The propeller was designed by using the Boeing KC-135 Winglet Supercritial Whitcomb airfoil. Testing was done using the Drone Propeller Thrust Testing Jig You can inspect the results below.

Part printed at slow speed, with a 0.2mm extruder nozzle at 0.04 height per layer. I deburred and cleaned the print using an X-ACTO Knife

After this, it was sanded with a piece of 500 grit sandpaper.

Here are the thrust measurements for a few voltage presets (also visible in the pictures taken):

  • 1.5V => 7.35 grams
  • 2V => 11.02 grams
  • 2.5V => 23.24 grams
  • 3V => 30.72 grams

The files you can download consist of all the pictures taken during the test, along with 6 txt files that contain airfoil coordinates, the STL files and the SLDPRT files. Should you want to play with the propeller, make sure you have a couple of 8520 coreless motors.

Use the SLDPRT files, should you want to adapt the propeller model to suit your own needs.

Notice: The airfoil plotted by using the matplotlib library for python.

title: Anet A8. Selector manual de presión del extrusor. (Anet A8. Manual Extruder Pressure Selector)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Anet A8. Selector manual de presión del extrusor. (Anet A8. Manual Extruder Pressure Selector)
Es una pequeña mejora para el extrusor que viene de serie en la impresora Anet A8, de esta forma se consigue un sistema con el que se pueda graduar la fuerza de empuje del extrusor. Tan solo hay que cambiar el muelle por uno un poco mas pequeño pero de igual fuerza, al mismo tiempo hay que colocar una tuerca de 3mm en el tornillo inferior que servira para calibrar la presión con la que empuja el extrusor.

El montaje que veis esta realizado para el sistema bowden que yo mismo diseñe, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2137423 pero este cambio se puede realizar en el sistema origina, aunque no este tan accesible.

It is a small improvement for the extruder that comes standard on the Anet A8 printer, in this way a system is achieved with which the thrust force of the extruder can be adjusted. Just replace the spring with a smaller one but with equal force, at the same time a 3mm nut must be placed in the lower screw that will serve to calibrate the pressure with which the extruder pushes.

The assembly you see is done for the bowden system that I designed, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2137423 but this change can be made in the original system, although it is not so accessible.

Printer:

Anet A8

author: enriquesmio

title: Raspberry Pi Camera Clamp for 3D Printer

description.text:
There are loads of Raspberry Pi camera cases out there but none seemed to do exactly what i wanted, so I put together my own design which clamps to the sloping strut of a RepRapPro Mendel (which is still doing great service!) This allows me to create timelapse videos of my 3D prints.
The case itself snaps together and the bracket allows the V2 camera unit to be levelled.
The design was printed in PETG and all the parts were designed with a 0.2mm tolerance which works fine (for me)! As long as your printer is reasonably well set up, you shouldn't have any problems. I can't offer any advice on printing in ABS as I never use it, I haven't printed it in PLA, but the design tolerances should be OK.
The design requires 3 M3 Cylinder head screws - a 16mm, a 10mm, and an 8mm, plus 3 M3 nuts. The 8mm needs to be exact, the others can be a bit longer. M3 slot heads will also fit, but I try to make things so that I only need one screwdriver to adjust everything.
I have included the Inventor files if anyone wants to tailor anything. Please bear in mind, the Inventor files are not fully dimensioned, nor are they put together in a particularly elegant way - it was a quick and dirty solution to a small problem.

Printer:

RepRapPro Mendel

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

35%

Putting it together

You might need to remove any spikes on the hinge pieces with a bit of wet and dry, but apart from that, there isn't anything to worry about regarding fit.

description.text:
This is my take on a device designed by Steve Rea. This device ended up being produced and sold by Arbor Scientific. Arbor's Rotational Inertia Demonstrator works amazingly well and is very repeatable. I highly recommend it. The cost really is quite reasonable for such a well built device. However, I decided to design a 3d printable one because our current physics teacher doesn't have the funds to buy a class set.

String is wrapped around one of the pulleys with a weight hanging from the string. There are three different pulleys to provide different amounts of torque. With an extra set of hex nuts the washers can be positioned different distances from the center of rotation changing the moment of inertia. There are a lot of experiments that students can do to investigate rotational motion.

Diameters of the three pulleys:

  • 24.5 mm
  • 49 mm
  • 73.5 mm

Update: I uploaded a new version with stops to keep the bearings from being pushed in too deep.

This was designed in TinkerCad.
https://tinkercad.com/things/53hXs6fGrxN

Notes:

Printed with 3 perimeters.

Parts List: (about $10 in parts/device)

  • 2 each Skateboard Bearings, 608ZZ 8x22x7
  • 4 each 6" long 1/4" hex bolts (or 1/4" threaded rods if you want longer arms)
  • 12 each 1/4" hex nuts
  • 40 each Fender washers, 1/4" hole 1.25" diameter

The bearings need to be de-greased first. The grease protects the bearings from water and road grit, but it will keep the bearings from spinning freely. I used acetone since we had it in the chemistry supplies. I just dropped them in a small beaker for 20-30 minutes. I found I also had to take them out of the acetone and spin them a couple of times then drop them back in. You need two bearings. One in each end for full support.

If you want to avoid using acetone do a little googeling for other ways to de-grease bearings. There's lots of stuff related to fidget spinners kicking around right now.

description.text:
Got an old phone that you could sell for £10 online? DONT! Turn it into a mini TV / Games console!

Simply print this Retro TV cover, stick your old smart phone into the back using hot glue or double sided tape, download a free TV app and games console emulator and off you go! Your old phone is still a computer (think of it as a Raspberry Pi with a screen), it should still receive WiFi, and be able to carry out multiple tasks such as online browsing.

My old phone is a Sony Xperia, the two holes for the headphone jack and micro USB align on this model but you may need to adjust their positioning as necessary. Same with the screen size, measure your screen (and outer dimensions of your phone) and adjust as necessary. You may also wish to experiment with a raft (or not) and infill requirements.

Enjoy!

description.text:
Steven's Cog Kit

This could be a great and fun educational toy, or perhaps just something for fun. The kit contains various sizes of cogs and gears, plus connecting rods to play about with.

Each cog is provided as a separate STL file, and are named after the number of teeth they have.

The cog frame is designed to take the connector rods. This allows the cogs to be put into many different positions. The frame also includes a space designed to take a small CD-ROM motor. Simply print the Cog21 (For Motor) cog, and you can then use the motor to power the cogs. You may need to make some adjustments depending on the motor used.

If you do not want to use a motor, there is a cog97 included that has a handle. Simply print the cog (Cog97 (With Handle)) and the handle (Handle For Cog97) and put them together.

You will also need to print out some connecting rods, to attach the cogs to the frame.

Also included is a spacer. This is a cog without any teeth that can be used to raise cogs above the frame.

The best thing to do is to simply print out all the parts and experiment, but most of all, have fun!

title: Diameter Calibration for Holes and Bosses on Replicator 2

description.text: This project helps Replicator 2 owners print parts with more accurate diameters for holes and bosses. The problem comes from Arc Compensation, an issue caused by slicing software that makes holes print out smaller than they were designed and bosses print out larger than they were designed. This is only a real problem when you are making through holes, holes that will be tapped, press fit components, etc. To solve this problem, I printed a bunch of different diameter holes and bosses, and measured each one with a set of calipers. I then plotted the expected diameters against the average error, which gives a calibration curve. The calibration curve allows you print more accurate diameter holes and bosses by accounting for the arc compensation errors during design. For example, holes with diameters less than 4.5mm have a 0.38mm error. So when designing a 3mm hole in your part, you would design it to be 3mm + 0.38mm = 3.38mm. Then, when you print out the part, the hole will actually come out to be 3mm. You can download the excel file with the measured data & calibration curve in the files section. Or, you can download the parts and run your own calibration for other slicers. See the Instructions section for more detail on the process & excel file.

To use the excel sheet, simply type in your desired diameter. The "approximate" correction uses the straight line approximations shown on the plot. The "fitted" correction uses the polynomial fit correction shown on the plot. CAUTION: Do NOT use the "fitted" correction outside for diameters outside of 1-10mm. The correction will show the actual diameter that you should design your part with in order for the hole or boss to print the correct diameter. For example, for a 2.5mm hole, the "approximate" correction shows you should design your hole to be 2.88mm. When you go to print it using the MakerWare slicer & Rep2, your hole will actually print out to 2.5mm. I typically use the "approximate" correction and it prints holes & bosses with a diameter error of less than 0.05mm. It works great for tapped holes, through holes, press fit, etc.

Download and print the two parts.  Then, using calipers, measure the actual diameter of each printed hole and boss.  Type the measured values into the A,B,C,D,E columns of the corrections spreadsheet.  The rest of the columns should be auto-calculated.  You will then have to manually update the "approximate" linear fit calculations just to the left of the chart.  Use your eye to determine the best locations for linear fit approximations.  The "fitted" polynomial line should auto-update.

comments.text: To anyone who reads this it is a long comment, but its worth the read if you are battling with hole sizes on your 3d printer.
comments.author: robbjosh

comments.text: Hi pcdangio - what you're describing here (small holes print smaller than expected, small pillars print wider than expected) is due to arc compensation. This is a well known problem in 3D printing, and as far as I know slicing softwares don't take this into account (so you have to). A general rule of thumb is that if you're printing a hole or pillar >6.5mm in diameter then it will be fine, but smaller diameters you need to add a little (for holes) or subtract a little (for pillars) in order to get the diameter you want. The page is here: http://reprap.org/wiki/ArcCompensationhttp://reprap.org/wiki/ArcComp.... Happy printing!

comments.text: Ahh you are exactly right, thank you for pointing me to the wiki article.  I'll try out a few prints using the compensation table they listed in there and compare it to the data I collected.  I'll post my findings in the info section after.

The solid-color mouse-head dangle was created for our 2017 DCL WBPC cruising group, The Panamaniacs! Instead of using printed paper cut-outs to hang off our lanyards (for identifying group members around the ship), 450 plastic dangles were 3D-printed in Neon Green and distributed at the group’s M&G on embarkment day. I'm not sure I'll ever want to print another again so hopefully the file (named 'mmrotate2A-2in.stl') can be fun for others now.

Along the way, my sister challenged me to a dual-extrusion version, resulting in the additional two peppermint spiral files, labeled with 'spiralMM0A_...'.

The actual size prints in the STL file are 2.5”x2.75”x0.25” and they have only been tested using PLA at 100% infill with 2 shells. Planning to also use these as a pendant, Christmas ornament, zipper pull, gift tag, bag flair, and whatever else I can think of. (Also hoping the uber-creative people here on Thingiverse find many more amazing ways it could be used or remixed.)

Just a final friendly reminder that this is meant to represent a certain company brand so please don’t p*ss The Mouse off trying to make any money off of this design. See you real soon [with your dangle]!

title: RC Tank that Prints without Support, Assembles without Hardware and Wires without Soldering

description.text:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XKXZaKyjVCw

  • Prints without support!
  • Assembles without hardware!
  • Wires without soldering!

This tank does not require a single bolt or nut. You just print the parts, put them together, connect the motors and electronics, and it's ready for battle. It shows excellent off-road capabilities, and turns on a dime. Each of this tank's two tracks is printed in a single piece, thus eliminating the need for assembly hardware.

The machine shown in the video below is powered with a Picaxe 20M2 microcontroller installed on a 300-hole mini-breadboard. There is also an H-bridge motor driver, an IR sensor, a couple of resistors and capacitors, and a whole bunch of jump cables. The entire set of electronic components used here can be bought on eBay for just a few dollars. The tank is operated with a regular Sony TV remote control.

For detailed and illustrated assembly instructions, please visit http://www.otvinta.com/download10.html.

if you like our tank, you may also like our Rubik's Cube Solving Robot:


All our models including this one were designed with Blender 3D. We have created many video tutorials on designing gears and mechanisms in Blender. To see them, please visit our YouTube channel at https://www.youtube.com/c/otvinta3d.

Print the tracks first.

The two single-piece tracks are the most difficult parts to print, so start with those. Once the part is printed, each track segment needs to be gently snapped loose so that it can rotate freely relative to its adjacent segment. Do not apply excessive force when doing it as it can cause an axis to break and ruin the entire part.
UPDATE 2017-07-23: Before you attempt to print the entire track, try printing the test piece, tank_2tracks.stl. If you can then break loose the two segments and have them rotate freely, proceed with the printing of the full tracks.

remixed_from.author: pheneeny
remixed_from.title: AM8 - Metal Frame for Anet A8

title: Mean Well LRS-350 mount/cover/inlet for AM8 frame

description.text:
Here's a mount design, for attaching a Mean Well LRS-350 power supply to pheneeny's AM8 remix. It securely mounts the supply to the printer, fully encloses the supply terminals and AC connections, and holds a switched/fused power inlet module.

The mount is designed to support the weight of the supply on the XY frame of the printer instead of the Z frame - there is a small connector that goes between the supply and the Z frame but this just serves to keep the supply from wobbling. The "step" in the bottom of the bracket is intended to clear the larger HBLFSDW5 Y-to-Z bracket that I'm using on my AM8 build, while keeping the AC inlet low on the printer frame and securely attached to it.

Overall it's a fairly heavy design that that requires about 100g of plastic, but the result is a stiff bracket that you won't worry about breaking if you pull on the power cord or transport the printer.

You'll need a snap-in, switched/fused IEC inlet such as this one. They can be found all over eBay and Aliexpress:
https://www.aliexpress.com/item/NEW-HIGH-QUALITY-Red-Light-Power-Rocker-Switch-Fused-IEC-320-C14-Inlet-Power-Socket-Fuse/32801835266.html

And to mount the LRS350 supply to the printer, you'll need four M4x8mm flat head screws. Do not use shorter or longer screws, shorter ones won't securely hold the supply and longer ones could potentially short out the guts of the power supply.

I printed with 35% infill in Cura, and used zig-zag supports with a 2.5mm line spacing. Since the cover contains line voltage, technically you should use a UL94 rated flame retardant filament, but I don't expect everyone here to be getting their builds UL certified :)

OpenSCAD files are attached. It's a disorganized mess, I apologize.

No pictures are up yet, they'll be up soon - I printed the bracket and mocked it up with the loose parts of my AM8 frame, and it seems to be OK.

title: vacuum robot Vorwerk kobold VR200 / Neato turret extension

description.text:
A vacuum robot is a great thing and ours is so flat, it can even go under the couch. Unfortunately it won't find its way out and will get stuck, so I had to design an extension to the turret, so the safety switch will tell it to turn around before it gets under the couch.

I know only one other person who owns the same robot and they have the same problem, so it seems like a useful thing.

The turret extension is available for 10mm, 15mm, 25mm and 35mm height, most people will be fine with 10 or 15mm.

To fix the extension on your robot you will need one short M3 screw, washer and nut. Have fun!

If you print it and it works, please share a photo. Thanks!

~Update: I included a 20mm version with a hole, which makes assembly a lot easier. Also, if you don't have a hex key, now you can print one. Good if you print this thing for your grandmother/relative/friend who doesn't own any tools. Works great after some sanding! I printed the hex key in low resolution and the ball head didn't come out good. But you don't really need it, so you can cut it off with a knife.

~Update 2: It works really great, with the 15mm version, the robot almost never gets stuck anywhere anymore.

comments.text: In the pictures it looks as if your extension were blocking the LIDAR, but I sure hope it's not ;)

title: TOS PADD
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
My take on the original series PADD. I based it on measurements of the original that have floated around the Internet and averaged them out. The holes are sized to fit Osram/Sylvania 662D lamp holders like the original. You can still find these online. The most common lens colors for the prop are, left to right, red, white, orange/amber.

Yes. It requires a big print bed, so I've included a 2-piece split version.

The loose pylon is meant to be glued in near the switch and the left light to provide stability and reduce flexing when the switch is pushed. I left it loose as you may want to move it depending on your electronics or what you use for the screen (the original used a Magic Slate toy.)

As for the back, you'll need to cut a sheet of something for the back. Printing a sheet of plastic seemed a bit pointless. I'm using a sheet of 12"x12" ABS, but Kydex, or other hobby plastic (or wood, for that matter) should work for you. The dimensions for the back are 210m x 265mm x 4mm. The blocks in the frame provide stability and a place to screw the back to.

post-processing

And yes, the pushbutton switch in the photo is the wrong one. It should be black, all black including the collar, and not sit too high.

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

title: Wacom Pen Holder For Kinesis Advantage

description.text:
If you, like me, are using a Wacom Bamboo or Intuos Pro tablet in combination with a Kinesis Advantage keyboard, then this might interest you.

This is pen holder hooks into the middle screw hole under the Kinesis and snaps into the seam and top edge of the keyboard to stay put. This way it will never get in the way like a holder standing on the desk would; with the clearance to the desk the edge of the tablet even goes under it making it possible to keep the tablet and keyboard as close together as they can go. It's designed to hold the pen at an angle to make it easy to get and put back, and the fit is good enough for it not to fall out easily.

Depending on material/tolerances/printer you might need to put a bit of double-sided tape between the holder and the keyboard to make sure it doesn't come loose if too much force is exerted (mine snaps into place and can hold the pen no problem, but I put some tape there just to be sure).

If you find you need to adjust the measurements for your setup all the variables are set in the beginning of the SCAD file so it's pretty straightforward to adjust, or you can use the Customizer to do the same thing.

I printed with PETG, wanted something durable but with a little bit of flex in the bottom 'plate' so it can flex and snap in place. PLA or ABS probably works just fine though.

title: Precision Piezo - Piezo20 Hotend Z Probe

description.text:
PLEASE NOTE: IF YOU HAVE BEEN REDIRECTED HERE FROM ALIEXPRESS OR ANY OTHER VENDOR OF THESE PRODUCTS OTHER THAN http://www.precisionpiezo.co.uk PLEASE BE AWARE THAT THEIR CLONES OF OUR PRODUCT ARE LESS LIKELY TO WORK, WILL NOT BE SUPPORTED BY US AND BUYING THEM WILL REDUCE OUR ABILITY TO DESIGN NEW PRODUCTS FOR THE REPRAP COMMUNITY.

PLEASE MAKE ONE YOURSELF OR BUY GENUINE.

Precision Piezo (http://www.precisionpiezo.co.uk)
Presents:

The Piezo20 hotend Z-Probe.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7ACaifW-XEA

New video guide to assemble this unit. https://goo.gl/6GehWS
Firmware setup latest can be seen here: http://forums.reprap.org/read.php?1,767998,page=9

Please see our website for more details.

Groovemount and Screw Mount (25mm spacing 2x m3) options to mount to your printer. The hotend clamps into the module using its groovemount in all 4 versions.

V1.12 Turrets for PCB now re-centred as new version PCB has an extension to clear the module for the endstop cable. Also screwmount version now comes with improved drilling guide/keyfob.
V1.11 Small changes to groove in the lower part for better tolerance. Offset PCB mounting to allow better clearance for endstop cable. Improved layout for better printing.
V1.1 Use brass inserts 4mmOD, 3mm length M3 thread
Otherwise identical.
V1.0 - Use heat pressed M3 nuts.

This object builds on the previous versions:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2152709
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2069480

I have also added by popular request the DXF files for the 64mm spacing magball metal effector and carriages for laser/waterjet cutting shown in the video (and carriages). These are designed by Lykle Schepers of Zesty Technology.

I have also added drilling guides for 20mm and 27mm piezos. Please drill them carefully, and away from food, preferably in your garage, the ceramic inside contains lead, and therefore should not be swallowed or inhaled.

comments.text: Hi, there is space in this unit for genuine e3d v6 as the pneumatic connector is within the groovemount on the heatsink. The clone v6 uses a much larger connector that won't fit. However there are several solution. 1) buy a genuine heatsink you can keep the heatbreak and heater block assembly if it's working for you. 2) unscrew the pneumatic connector, insert the heatsink, relocate the connector above the sensor unit somewhere and run a ptfe guide tube from it down into your hotend.

comments.text:

comments.author: DjDemonD

comments.text: The only critical dimensions are that the piezo disc is centralised in the filament path that it is supported ideally on its periphery. The lower part should, for optimal results should press into the disc more centrally this generates the flexing which makes it more sensitive. The rest of the module should be capable of holding the upper and lower parts and preloading the disc but does not have to be of any specific size. I chose the smallest size that was easy to print and contained all the parts based on previous prototypes. Ensure the holes between the upper and lower part do not bind on the screws, as they should be able to "slide" albeit only 0.1mm.
comments.author: Vanquisher

title: Stackable C-Rotor Vertical Wind Turbine  VAWT

description.text:
The C-Rotor is a VAWT where it is not 100% clear, where and when it was invented. There is a pretty good documentation on www.daswindrad.de (in German only).

You can either print the bottom part only once and use the cover, or you can alternatively print the bottom several times and stack them (twisted by 60 degrees), using the cover only on the uppermost part. I am using 2 bottoms and the thing spins nicely in my garden at pretty low winds.

I glued all parts together with semi liquid cyan acrylate glue.

It is designed for use with 608 ball bearings ( 8mm rod, 22 mm outer diameter, 7 mm high). I am only using 2 bearings and do not install one in the middle to prevent mechanical stress. The bearing covers are protecting the bearings a bit from rain.

Comparison to Ugrinsky Rotor:
I have the C-Rotor and the Ugrinsky running in my garden since a while now. I did not make measurements and I did not test them under a load. However, comparing them as free running rotors over a longer time in many different wind situations, the Ugrinsky provides significantly better performance. It starts spinning at lower wind speeds and produces higher RPM. The C-Rotor is an interesting design but the Ugrinsky is better, in my personal opinion.

comments.text:
Which turbine is better C-rotor or Ugrinsky ?
I want to post the comparative film on vawt.ro
Please send movie.
comments.author: Apis21

comments.text: I have the C-Rotor and the Ugrinsky running in my garden since a while now, using the same size of the rotor and the same bearings. I did not make measurements and I did not test them under a load. However, comparing them as free running rotors over a longer time in many different wind situations, the Ugrinsky provides significantly better performance. It starts spinning at lower wind speeds and produces higher RPM.  I think a comparison video is difficult, because the rotors are close to a corner of my house and I am living on a hillside facing south with thermal conditions. I can never tell exactly, how laminar the airflow is in that spot and where exactly the wind comes from. But I keep comparing the two rotors in many different wind directions and speeds. There is no doubt, that the Ugrinsky rotor always starts earlier and turns faster.

title: Online Particulate Matter Sensor (Temperature/Humidity as well)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
[Edit 03/06/17] Added a sturdier version (v0.6) with thicker walls and with better support for nodeMCU.

3D Printing is known to produce particulate while heating plastics, especially ABS.

There are a lot of different approach to mitigate this health risk, using HEPA filter, activated carbon, or venting the air outside. Honnestly you just presume the efficiency of any filtering method, so the only way to know is to measure it.

This thing is based on PlanTower PMS5003 dust sensor. This laser dust sensor can sense particulate starting from 0.3 µm and above, and is a reasonnable price/efficiency ratio so that you can determine if your air is heavilly polluted or not. Trust me, smell is not a good way to do that :)

Measurement is displayed on the LCD screen, which provide real time Temperature, Humidity, calculated AQI (Air Quality Index, check https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Air_quality_index ) and PM 1.0

In addition it sends every data to thingspeak every minute, or to a MQTT broker, depending of options activated in the source code. You need to create a thingspeak free account, create two channel according to the ino file and get the write API code into the ino file before compilation. You need to put a wifi SSID and password as well.

BOM:

  • PlanTower PMS 5003 (20~30 € on ebay). Datasheet available here: http://www.aqmd.gov/docs/default-source/aq-spec/resources-page/plantower-pms5003-manual_v2-3.pdf?sfvrsn=2
  • LCD 1602 with I2C interface (2~3 € on ebay)
  • DHT11 or DHT22 (1~5 € on eaby)
  • 10 kohm resistor
  • NodeMCU 1.0 (around 5 € on ebay)
  • Dupont connector set (some €)
  • Dupont Crimping tool (from 10 € to 50 € or more, quality may vary a lot !!)

The wiring is described as one of the image, the Fritzing fzz file is provided as well.

NodeMCU coding rely on Arduino ESP8266 board addition, available with installation instruction from https://github.com/esp8266/Arduino

Code is available on https://github.com/ChrisP-Git/PartSense. The code is improving and support ThingSpeak, MQTT brokers and Domoticz feeding through MQTT now..

Just print both part, put the different part inside the different position, using Dupont connectors to make clean wiring. The cover need to be screwed to body, then can be screwed under the top of you enclosure.

This thing is experimental and is a first step, it may be improved and remixed, please share your makes or what you have done from it :)

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

No

description.text:
Usage

Clips an 1mm CFK plate (220x220) onto the A8's normal heating bed.
CFK plate and heating bed together together, having a thickness of approx 4.2mm.
Use same corner 4 times. No additional material needed.

Installation

No need to diassemble the plate nor the heating bed, screw or spring. Just push down the spring from the beds bottom towards its carrier using a pliers or a screwdriver. Then snap-in the corner and release the spring.
After spring has been released, the corner will be held in place by the spring.

Pros

Very tiny CFK plate holder which is unlikely to collide with any parts attached to the printer head as eg. bed level sensor, cooler ducts or the like.

title: Gesture control using distance sensors chain

description.text:
This is an autonomous chain of laser distance sensors solution using LS53L0X boards with embeeded VL53l0 time of flight distance sensor and STM32 microcontroller.
Connected by bluetooth with an android phone all measurements are simultaneously available.
With this solution, it's possible to create a gesture control solution.

Master box is powered with 2xAAA battery. A bluetooh module is embeeded.
Salves are connected in serial.

Bill Of Material ==> see attached picture

Master box assembly:
1- Solder 5 headers on LS53L0X (pins RX, PWM, GND, VCC + 1 external)(see dedicated picture)
2- Solder HC-06 module and battery holder to LS53L0X (see dedicated picture)
3- assemble the box using screws to fix battery holder to the box

Slave box assembly
1- Solder 2x 4 headers on LS53L0X (pins RX, PWM, GND, VCC + INTR1, MSCL, MSDA, GND) (see board picture)
2- assemble the box

Gui
https://gist.github.com/gilisymo/9cd3dbf00379142cf3741133a8a37dac

Code

remixed_from.title: Acro Whoop frames remixed for Inductrix

title: Camera, Motor mount & Battery Mount for the Blade Inductrix, Ragg-E & LynxHeli Frames

description.text:
These files provide a camera & Battery mount solution for the Blade Inductrix (the original micro kwad), Ragg-E Micro FPV, and LynxHeli spider 65 frames. The camera mount is currently tilted at 25-degrees.

I have also added a remix on Camel Kucuk & Tom Ashley Ragg-E micro motor cap too.

And as always I would really appreciate your thoughts, comments and feedback...

The kit I used

  1. Micro AIO Camera 5.8G 25mW https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B06XK9KX1Z/ref=ox_sc_act_title_1?smid=AP0ABZZM4QKJV&psc=1
  2. NewBeeDrone - BeeBrain v.1 - Micro Brushed Flight Controller - https://newbeedrone.com/collections/beeductrix-inductrix/products/the-beebrain-v-1-cleanflight-betaflight-compatible-flight-control-for-the-tinywhoop-inductrix-quad
  3. NewBeeDrone -BDR Gold edition brushed 6mm motor - https://newbeedrone.com/collections/beeductrix-inductrix/products/bee-dynamic-rotor-gold-edition-6x15mm-brushed-motor-set
  4. NewBeeDrone - NitroNectar Power - Nitro Nectar 250mAh HV LiPo Battery - https://newbeedrone.com/collections/lipobatteries/products/newbeedrone-high-voltage-nitro-nectar-210-30-60c-mah-battery
  5. PLA, PLA+, Flexible PLA , ABS or TPU from Rigid Ink https://rigid.ink/products/flexible-pla-1-75-mm-0-03-mm-tolerance-filament?variant=34085486279
  6. 14 x M1.2 mm 3mm PANS Head Screw Silver - https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B01M1CI4PA/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Existing Frames

  1. Blade Inductrix frames £7.55 + P&P - https://www.horizonhobby.co.uk/Blade-Inductrix-Main-Frame.htm?SessionId=&a=article&ProdNr=094BLH8706&gclid=Cj0KEQjwgODIBRCEqfv60eq65ogBEiQA0ZC5-ftdY8J0-_P3PCz6qQ4jjNpS39kilN2cnSsRdI6oqNYaAsJ68P8HAQ
  2. Ragg-E Micro FPV £19.99 + P&P - http://www.dronejunkie.co.uk/shop/ragg-e-whoop-frame-set/
  3. Lynx Heli Spider 65 FPV Racer $19.95 + P&P https://www.lynxheli.com/index.php?cPath=373_367_395&osCsid=64d41eeaa5639bca63fe8c1bfe030469

Design References

  1. Blade Inductrix the Orignal Micro Kwad -http://www.bladehelis.com/Inductrix/
    https://www.dronejunkie.co.uk/shop
  2. Microdure - https://www.facebook.com/Microdure/
  3. Tom Ashley - Ragg-E Micro FPV - http://www.ragg-e.co.uk/micro-quad-frames
  4. Lynx Heli Spider 65 FPV Racer - https://www.lynxheli.com/index.php?cPath=373_367_395&osCsid=64d41eeaa5639bca63fe8c1bfe030469
  5. [email protected] - Motor Mount Design Inspiration Micro Drone Specialist for; drones, spare & good advice.

remixed_from.author: satchy
remixed_from.title: Car holder / mount for Samsung S8+

description.text:
Tried to add space for a headphone aux cable. First time using 3D slash.

customized with 3D Slash!
OpenSCAD code to create a six-sided die with arbitrary text on each side.  (I was amazed such a thing did not already exist.)

Currently uses and requires more_fontz (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:13677). Open the file in OpenSCAD and enter your text for each side in the side#text definition quotes. Do a test render and adjust the other parameters for the best look:
diesize = size of the die
rounding = radius of the edge curvature
textdepth = depth of the inset text; below 2 seems problematic
textheight = used to properly align the text on the sides Since I could not find a way to change the size of the more_fontz output directly, I concentrate on proportions to get the die sized nicely around the text in OpenSCAD and then do the final adjust for size in RepG.

comments.text: Any way to change the size of the font?

title: Mounting Clip for a GE 10168 Slim line Fluorescent Under Cabinet Light Fixture, 14-Inch

description.text:
While trying to decide where to mount this light, I had lost the mounting tabs that were included in the package.  
This tab mounts the lamp closer to the cabinet than the original part.  It is almost hidden from view.  
This is my first attempt to recreate a replacement part. The part was printed, installed, and worked fine.  
The mounting hole is 4mm in diameter. I installed it using #6 -1/2" screw.  
The part was created in Sketchup, and the file is included.

Printed on home brew RepRap.
Sliced Using CURA.
ABS
.4mm Nozzle
.25mm Layer Height
60% infill. 20% did not provide enough strength, but something in between may work.

title: Functional M3 Nut
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a fully functional M3 hex nut. The threads were designed to mate with screws with ISO M coarse thread profile. This was done as an experiment to test the possibility of printing threads with such a small pitch. I hypothesized that it would not work and that the screw would simply act as a tap. I printed one, and it works! This result was surprising. Since publishing this thing, I have repeated the experiment with success. I even cut a cross section of a print to observe the threads. Of course they are not perfectly ISO compliant, but they do follow the profile enough to function with ISO compliant threads.

This makes a good experiment print to test the limitations of your printer.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

For best results, make your first layer slightly taller than normal.
Using the ISO spec sheet for coarse pitch metric thread (M), I modelled the nut in Blender.

comments.text:
What an achievement ! It is the steel screw that makes the ISO profile, not the printing :-). Too bad the hex is not ISO though !
Seriously, it is far better to just use a drill to get the nut hole to be 3- 0.5 (pitch) = 2.5 and tap or even just drive the screw that will act as a tap. It is just plastic !
Besides if you need "plastic" screws and nuts you will never get proper printed nuts and bolts as strong as cheap available everywhere Nylon ones. There are only a few cases where printed bolts, nuts are useful and not in the small diam.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: Hmm.  This was done as an experiment.  The ISO profile was indeed achieved through the printing.  The steel screw's threads grabbed the printed threads perfectly, and turned with ease.  My first layer was a bit squashed as my heat bed, though level, was a touch too high, causing said first layer to ooze out the side a bit. This was the only point where any unusual amount of force was required.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
Common looking at the poor quality of your print, the thread was not correct but the screw grab it and made it correct ! Do a cutaway of the just printed nut, magnify it and show !
As I wrote, no point in even threading, just screw and the screw will act as a tap !
I made REAL printed nuts in Igus filament for TR8 lead screw, big sizes nuts for plastic stuff like Dremel nut, etc... Once again, no point to "print" thread except in a few specific cases and for large pitch (abouve 1mm). Same for gears, no point making gears with module less than 1. And yet, the quality is not great.
comments.author: SirFarthingtonSmythe

comments.text: Ok.  Well, as I mentioned, it was an experiment, and the screw did not act as a tap.  That was the point of my experiment; to determine if the screw would simply act as a tap, which is what I hypothesized would be the case.  I was surprised to find my hypothesis to be incorrect.  It was a shocking surprise.  I am well capable of telling the difference between a screw acting as a tap and one that fits correctly.  That said, you are of course welcome to your opinion, and just as welcome to perform your own experiments to see for yourself.  Mind you, a single success does not necessarily constitute the norm; it could very well be the exception rather than the rule.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
You claimed ISO, so do a cutaway of a just printed nut, enlarge it and compare to the ISO profile. I never "experiment" in this case because I know what ISO means, class of accuracy, thread cutting or forming ... and there is no way to print such details with a string a molten plastic about as big as half the pitch l !
Do you have a technical background ?
comments.author: SirFarthingtonSmythe

comments.text: The thread pitch of M3 coarse thread is 0.5 mm which is 5 times the printed layer height (0.1 mm).  Just like it is not possible to draw a circle on a computer monitor, it is possible to closely represent one.  While it is true that obtaining a 100% ISO accurate thread on a 3D printer with limited resolution is not possible, it is completely plausible to closely represent such; it is perfectly possible to fit 5 rectangles into the space of a triangle.  Close enough, so that the threads will mate well with their ISO compliant counterpart.  I mentioned that I used the ISO specs when modelling the nut.  There was never a claim of 100% ISO adherence on my part.  You made reference to the ISO profile being created by the threads of steel screw.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
OK, point taken, but you should present it as is. People here are mainly in the design of spool holders and boxes and could conclude they can 3D print "good" small screws instead of using proper metal, nylon ones and even better in many cases, self taping screws.
TIP too :-)

title: Raspberry Pi Zero MAX7219 LED Case

description.text:
I have a small YouTube channel reviewing technology and I wanted to have something in my studio that displayed how many subscribers I have. So I decided to use a Raspberry Pi Zero with a LED display mainly because it's cheap and has a low power consumption.

The basic idea was to create something that could securely hold the Raspberry Pi and the LED display without any screws and so far it has worked quite well. It's still a work in progress and some fittings might be more loose depending on the quality of your printer, but this is so it can be printed on any printer. There's nothing more frustrating than spending hours on printing to find the parts don't fit!

I have included plugs for the board pillars, but the cables should be enough to secure the board down.

Please be kind on me as this is my first ever design and if you do use it I'd love it if you dropped me a tweet @theNBguy. Also I will be uploading a full 'how to' video to my YouTube channel soon.

Printed using PLA 1.75mm on a Prusa i3

Version 1.5
Display has been properly aligned from V1.4 on both Case and Lid. Rear text indentation has been made more prominent. Plugs have been included to secure the Raspberry Pi if required.
Note: Only use the plugs if you don't intend on removing the board as it may snap the fragile pillars on removal

Version 1.4
Introduced text and vent holes on rear. Adjusted HDMI port and rear text with more of an indent. Also added a support for Raspberry PI board as when force was applied by plugging into ports caused the pillars to break. Slightly adjusted lid overhang to make less of a gap.

Version 1.3
Enlarged the pillars slightly for less movement and more strength. An issue with the HDMI cutout causing difficulty installing Raspberry Pi board.

Version 1.2
Slight adjustment with placement of Raspberry Pi to allow cables to not touch the left pillar. LED mount adjusted to make display flush against the case.

Version 1.1
Issue with pillars fixed and slight change with the way the LED display fits against the case. Also first basic version of lid created.

Version 1.0
Basic shell for raspberry Pi. It worked well but as the MicroUSB ports hang over the board causing difficult installation over the pillars.

title: Nintendo Switch rotating and detachable wall mount (No scratching)

description.text:
Video of assembly and use: https://youtu.be/RFCN4XdV-yo

I made this Nintendo Switch wall mount, as i like to play the switch in my bed, but its not very comfy to hold the switch while laying in the bed, and i like to lay sideways and play. So i made this wall mount that can turn into any angle you like, so you can play while laying on your side, it can of course also be used as a normal wall mount.

The wall mount is detachable and uses a module system, this means that you could make a normal stand that had the module connector and this system would work too, im planning to do this in the future, so its a multi tool. If you wanted you could also use this system for making a mount for the car.

There's a hole in the bottom so the switch can charge while playing. I made the holder specifically for not scratching the switch, as that has been a problem for some. The case only touches the metal rails and the two holes in the bottom

REMEMBER TO PRINT IN RIGHT ORIENTATION, especially the holder that slides on the switch, the indents should be facing upward

If they don't connect correctly, try cutting the edges of the holders module connector.

If people like it i will make a stand that uses this system aswell so you can seamlessly switch between using a stand and a wall mount

Settings;
Printed in green PLA
2 mm height
50 mm/s speed

description.text: Generated by NASA OpenVSP
I lost one protection cap for those anti-theft-screws on my Beemer. So I made a new one. Simple but it does the trick. 24 mm in inner diameter, 26 mm outside. May fit other models as well.

This is a six round version of my other 38 Special/.357 Magnum Speed Loader.

This is a Work in Progress and was done on request so I can't test it personally as to whether it fits (insert your revolver model here). The cylinder spacing dimensions for this were taken from a HKS 10 speed loader so if those work with your revolver there is a good chance this might too. (key word being "Might".)

There are only three pieces to the speed loader and it is held together with a single 6/32 x1/2" button head screw. I tapped the center hole before inserting the screw but you might be able to just self thread it in.

You will have to sand the holes to allow the rounds to fit smoothly.

The lock has to be inserted correctly for it to work properly so a little trial and error is in order when assembling it. This one should unlock the rounds with a clockwise turn. The nubs on the lock may wear out after time but I haven't tested them that much yet.

I've also included a loading block for this but I haven't printed this one personally so if you do and there are problems let me know.

If you have any questions or problems with the files or fitment of the parts just let me know and I will try to fix them.

Remember to tip your waiters designers if you like the service.... thanks for looking

comments.text: works great! I'm using it for a dan Wesson 6" revolver - the hand grip on the gun gets in the way abit defiantly speeds up the reloading. at first I thought how the hell are you going to turn it if you screw it together but then realised it would work!! thank you
comments.author: Siggster101

comments.text: I'm confused, how is this used?  The lock and body are keyed together, so I can't release and capture rounds.  What am I missing?
comments.author: -Josh-

comments.text: Rounds are inserted into the speed loader and the knob is turned (about a 1/16 of a turn) to lock them in place.  (The starish shaped pattern of the knob bottom turns over the rims of the cases to lock them in place)  After firing the rounds in the cylinder of the firearm, you open the cylinder and the spent casings are ejected and you can then insert live rounds into the cylinder all at once with the speed loader. You then twist the knob to release the rounds, remove the loader, close the cylinder, and continue shooting.

remixed_from.title: Magnetic bracket for doors and enclosures

description.text:
Saw this design and wanted to use it, but I didn't have any of the required magnets. I did happen to have 1" x 1/32" N52 neodymium rare earth magnets from an earlier project. If you're interested in them, here's the link:
https://www.kjmagnetics.com/proddetail.asp?prod=DX001-N52

Also added a cross-section view of how I adjusted the screw cap. I left ~0.5mm gap between the bracket and screw cap, just so I wouldn't have to sandpaper the sides down if it was too tight a fit. I also left 0.9mm gap for the 1/32" thick magnet. If this turns out to be too little or too much, I can adjust accordingly and re-upload. Once I have these printed, I'll add pics.

Oh, I also added some fillets just because :) I prefer less blocky designs. It may end up needing them without the curves, so I'll re-upload if needed.

Cheers!

remixed_from.author: The_Craft_Dude
remixed_from.title: Raspberry pi (Macintosh) G4 Cube Mini (Raspberry Pi 2 + 3 Case)

title: Remixed G4 Power Mac cube for Raspberry Pi

description.text:
I loved the original concept, but it didn't quite work for my needs. Here's what I changed:
-Combined the core "bottom," "front," and "pillars" pieces to print as one part that doesn't require gluing.
-Added another whole through which one can install or remove a microSD card
-Tweaked the case to have a cavity for an apple logo badge

All these changes are based on an actual print of the original work (Thanks, The_Craft_Dude!).

I still don't know how the lock is supposed to work, but the core stays put with friction for me.

comments.text:
Hi, I printed it and I know, how the "lock" is supposed to work. It is not a lock, it is more a stopper...
The original design has a design error and you didn't see it, that's why you couldn't figure out how it works.
To make the design work, the "cushions" and the "backplate" have to be swapped or the holes in the bottom have to be mirrored. The backplate has to be where the stopper is located and the cushions have to be in front, where the logo is.
Other (perhaps easier) option would be to swap the two holes in the sides of the cover part.
I really like the Pi-Case with your optimizations, so could I ask you to modify the model ? I can't do it myself because I'm new to 3D-Printing and CAD and can't do this myself.
comments.author: patricherz

comments.text: I'm not entirely sure I understand what you're describing.  The only thing I did was import the parts into TinkerCad and combined them (and added a hole), so perhaps you can do the same with the original design.  Alternately, I'll try to look into it this weekend.
comments.author: patricherz

comments.text:
Difficult to explain in english... if you take a look at the case part, the core should be inserted with the big wall side to the back of the case (where the oval cutout is). So, the stopper/lock stops the big wall side of the core inside the case. If you do that, you will notice that the holes for USB and SD-Card in the case part are reversed.
I think the Craft Dude didn't notice because he didn't print it. I think he reversed the upper and downer side of the base plate of the core.

title: Low Poly Crystal Decoration/Lamp
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I designed these little crystal-looking things to be small decorations, or if you're feeling like a DIY project, LED-lit lamps. Photos above were printed on my MP Maker select v2.1 (a.k.a. Wanhao Duplicator i3 v2.1) using Maker Geeks Maker Series red PLA and Maker Geeks Dragons Metallic Gold PLA.

Each model is made to print in vase mode: I recommend printing it in this way for speed and because the single perimeter of the model will allow light to shine through even if the filament you use is not labeled as translucent.

If you print these, be sure to hit the "I made one" button! I'd love to see your prints!

I am yet to make my prints into LED lamps, but I plan to, so expect an update on my process for that soon!

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

I used .1mm, but it shouldn't matter

Infill:

N/A

Notes:

IMPORTANT: These models are tiny by default, so I recommend scaling them up in your slicer to 400-600%.

  • Use vase mode ("Spiralize outer contour" in Cura)
  • I had some weird under-extrusion on my first layer only but YMMV
  • It's a good idea to make sure your slicer's ending G code section includes retracting the filament a good bit to ensure a nice point at the top
  • Please note that each file, while similar looking, is different from one another, not iterations of design

title: Stackable Ugrinsky Vertical Wind Turbine VAWT

description.text:
This VAWT uses a design, developed by K.A.Ugrinsky in 1946. It is basically a Miller rotor with integrated Lenz 2 features.

You can either print the bottom part only once and use the cover, or you can alternatively print the bottom several times and stack them (twisted by 90 degrees), using the cover only on the uppermost part. I am using 2 bottoms and the thing spins nicely in my garden at pretty low winds. If you print both, this one and also the C-Rotor in my other design, you can directly benchmark the two designs.

I glued all parts together with semi liquid cyan acrylate glue.

It is designed for use with 608 ball bearings ( 8mm rod, 22 mm outer diameter, 7 mm high). I am only using 2 bearings and do not install one in the middle to prevent mechanical stress. The bearing covers are protecting the bearings a bit from rain.

Comparison to C-Rotor:
I have the C-Rotor and the Ugrinsky running in my garden since a while now. I did not make measurements and I did not test them under a load. However, comparing them as free running rotors over a longer time in many different wind situations, the Ugrinsky provides significantly better performance. It starts spinning at lower wind speeds and produces higher RPM.
